protocol_name: Induction of root symbioses in common bean
protocol_name_html: Induction of root symbioses in common bean
description: A hallmark of legume plants is their ability to establish mutualistic symbioses with Rhizobium bacteria and arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (Rhizophagus irregularis). These symbionts help in providing nutritional benefits to the host plants. Herein, we provide a protocol to inoculate the common bean for the induction of symbiont colonization. This protocol has been routinely used in our laboratory with high reproducibility.
protocol_affiliation: Ciencias Agrogenómicas, Escuela Nacional de Estudios Superiores Unidad León- Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México (UNAM), León, Guanajuato, México.
manuscript_citation: Nanjareddy K, Arthikala M, Gómez B, Blanco L, Lara M (2017) Differentially expressed genes in mycorrhized and nodulated roots of common bean are associated with defense, cell wall architecture, N metabolism, and P metabolism. PLoS ONE 12(8): e0182328. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0182328
keywords: Legumes, Phaseolus vulgaris, Rhizobium tropici, AM fungi
authors: Kalpana Nanjareddy, Manoj-Kumar Arthikala, Brenda-Mariana Gómez, Lourdes Blanco, Miguel Lara

components.data: About one gram of Rhizophagus irregularis spores (Symplanta®, Germany) were dissolved in 10 ml sterile water.

components.data: Using hemocytometer adjust the spore count to 1000 spores/ml by dilution with sterile water.

components.data: To induce mycorrhizal colonization, inoculate 1 ml of culture (prepared from step 1 & 2) at the root zone of 5 day old common bean seedlings maintained in pots containing sterile vermiculite.
components.name: Description

components.data: Maintain the inoculated plants in growth chambers with a 16-h photoperiod and 65% relative humidity at 28 °C.

components.data: For induction of root nodules, inoculate Rhizobium tropici strain CIAT899 (this species is compatible to common bean) 100 ml of PY medium (0.5 g peptone, 0.3 g yeast extract) supplemented with 7 mM ml–1 CaCl2 and 20 mg ml–1 nalidixic acid and incubate at 30 °C for 24 h with shaking at 200 rpm. NOTE: Any specific antibiotics could be used in case of transgenic Rhizobium.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: For induction of root nodules, inoculate Rhizobium tropici strain CIAT899 (this species is compatible to common bean) 100 ml of PY medium (0.5 g peptone, 0.3 g yeast extract) supplemented with 7 mM ml–1 CaCl2 and 20 mg ml–1 nalidixic acid and incubate at 30 °C for 24 h with shaking at 200 rpm. NOTE: Any specific antibiotics could be used in case of transgenic Rhizobium.
